name: 4-hydroxy-3-methoxybenzoic acid
Reason: The basic unit for 4-hydroxy-3-methoxybenzoic acid is benzene, which has a melting point around 5.5°C. The hydroxy group (-OH) is expected to significantly increase the melting point because it is capable of forming strong intermolecular hydrogen bonds, which we might estimate as a +150°C increase. The methoxy group (-OCH3) is an electron-donating group and also polar, and it may raise the melting point; I predict a more modest increase, around +20°C. Likewise, the carboxylic acid group (-COOH) is also capable of strong intermolecular hydrogen bonding and will raise the melting point further; we might estimate an additional +100°C for this effect. Thus, compared to benzene, we have a cumulative effect from these functional groups.

name: 4-hydroxy-3-methoxybenzoic acid
Reason: The basic unit for 4-hydroxy-3-methoxybenzoic acid is benzene, which has a melting point around 5.5°C. The hydroxy group (-OH) substantially increases the melting point due to its capacity for strong hydrogen bonding; the increase can be estimated at approximately +100°C. The methoxy group (-OCH3) is less influential but still increases the melting point due to its polarity and electron-donating nature; a plausible increase for melting point attributed to this group is about +10°C. The carboxylic acid group (-COOH) also greatly enhances the melting point via hydrogen bonding; an expected increase is around +90°C. All the functional groups collectively elevate the melting point significantly.
